citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
At the time of inspection, a single housed turkey in the barn was being treated for sores on the bottom of both feet
(“bumble foot”). The turkey was full weight bearing on both feet and was not observed to be limping. The facility
representative explained that for five days both feet were on a daily regimen of cleaning followed by application of
Neosporin ointment and padding and re-wrapped with veterinary bandage wrap; however, the attending veterinarian had
not been notified to examine the animal. The attending veterinarian was contacted during the inspection to arrange for
assessment and treatment oversight.
The facility must use appropriate methods to prevent, control, diagnose, and treat diseases and injuries of animals. When
problems with animal health or behavior occur the attending veterinarian must be notified in a timely manner to provide for
adequate assessment and ensure the appropriate diagnosis and treatment.
Correct by April 11, 2024.

A developed contingency plan was not available at the time of inspection. A complete written contingency helps facilities
prepare and plan for the humane care and handling of animals in the event of an emergency or disaster.
Correct by developing and maintaining a written emergency plan that is tailored to the facility and provides for the humane
handling, treatment, transportation, housing, and care of animals on hand in the event of an emergency or disaster. All
employees must be trained on their roles and responsibilities within this plan. The plan must also be reviewed annually,
and any changes documented and maintained.
Correct by April 16, 2024.

citations.desc: Environment enhancement to promote psychological well-being.
citations.narrative:
At the time of inspection, there was no documented environmental enhancement plan for birds. An environmental
enhancement plan is essential in promoting the psychological well-being of birds through social housing, environmental
enrichment, and considerations for birds needing special attention.
Correct by developing, documenting, and following an appropriate plan for environmental enhancement as directed by the
attending veterinarian and in accordance with the currently accepted professional standards.
Correct by April 16, 2024.
This is a 1st Re-License Inspection for a Class “C” license. The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the
applicant.
All items must be in compliance within 2 more inspection(s) or by June 8, 2024 or the applicant will forfeit the license fee
and must wait 6 months to reapply. Please contact your inspector to schedule your next Re-License Inspection.
Regulated activity can continue under your existing USDA license until it expires.
